awd_titl_txt: Coherent Multidimensional Spectroscopy of the Oxygen Evolving Complex in Photosystem II
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Wright at University of Wisconsin continuously develops coherent multidimensional spectroscopy (CMDS) by expanding its capability of measuring molecular motions.  CMDC is a spectroscopic technique to fingerprint a molecule, which helps scientists to distinguish different molecules present in complex samples.  In this project, Professor Wright uses a pair of laser pulses to create specific responses from different electrons in a molecule and then follow the change of their energy levels over a very wide range of time scales.  He then uses this technique to study how vitamin B12 works and how green plants use sunlight to make oxygen at the molecular level.  Studying these two questions could help us to better understand how human body works and how to harness solar energy more effectively.  Professor Wright also works with an instrument company on the commercialization of the CMDS technique by reducing the cost and make it easier to use by other scientists. Through this project, Professor Wright provides research opportunities to graduate, undergraduate, and secondary school students.  He is also passionate about using active learning methods to prepare future STEM students for better national competitiveness and works closely with summer students from Spelman College. 

Professor Wright's project has two specific goals - understanding the enzymatic mechanism for vitamin B12's catalysis of ethanolamine degradation and the mechanism by which the oxygen evolving complex in photosystem II makes oxygen.  The vitamin B12 mechanism serves as a model for understanding enzymatic reactions.  The OEC mechanism is one of the grand challenges of chemistry, particularly for developing solar energy.  For both systems, Professor Wright uses CMDS to create quantum mechanical superpositions of vibrational and electronic states that provide the selectivity and structural details required to define the mechanisms with quantum state resolution.  Specifically, he is working to (1) develop a pump-CMDS probe to create a 3D spectrum; (2) to study the Co-C bond cleavage in a cobalamin-ethanolamine ammonida lyase (EAL)-ethanolamine (EA) complex to investigate the enzymatic reaction converting ethanolamine to acetaldehyde and ammonia; and (3) to characterize the electronic and vibrational states of oxygen evolving complexes (OEC) in photosystem II to understand the water oxidation mechanism. In addition, Professor Wright (1) continues his development of active learning methods in undergraduate and graduate courses; (2) works with students from Spelman College through a REU program; and (3) plans to disseminate CMDS through web site tutorials, educational materials, publications and conferences.

por.por_cntn:
The original invention of the laser (1960) was greeted with great excitement because it provided light waves that oscillated like the radio waves used in nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). It would create the optical analogue of NMR. The coherent oscillation of radio waves was the key property that allowed NMR to see the coupling between molecules that control almost every property essential to science, technology, and medicine. This capability has therefore allowed NMR to become a dominant methodology in the world today, the most familiar being magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in radiology. However, NMR?s capabilities are strongly limited because it has a very narrow range of frequencies and is therefore sensitive only to hydrogen, carbon, nitrogen, and a few other nuclei. Furthermore, it is not capable of measuring low concentrations. Lasers generated great excitement because they created coherent oscillations of light that ranged over the entire electromagnetic spectrum from x-rays to far infrared and allowed measurements at trace concentrations. That would allow it to be sensitive to everything. That promise, however, has not yet been kept.

In ~2000, scientists, including ourselves, succeeded in creating an exact NMR analogue. Even though this analogue could be used throughout the  electromagnetic spectrum, its range of frequencies at any point in the spectrum was just as limited in range as NMR. Nevertheless, it has allowed detailed study of chemical dynamics at ultrafast time scales and it has become a dominant methodology in physical chemistry. The fundamental difficulty encountered lies in the method itself. NMR and the optical analogues differ widely in the range of interest- very narrow for NMR and very wide for an optical analogue. So, copying the method used in modern NMR also doomed the optical analogue to very narrow spectral ranges. That has strongly limited its applications to ultrafast dynamics.

The research in our NSF program has succeeded in developing a different approach that uses the original method of NMR, namely scanning the laser frequencies across the entire range from the x-ray through the infrared. This  method is based on creating a quantum mechanically entangled Floquet state. A Floquet state is a mixture of vibrational and electronic states that are being forced to coherently oscillate at their individual frequencies by lasers that are tuned to their resonances. The resonances are much like simultaneously pushing children on swings, each at their resonant frequencies. Our methodology has now succeeded in extending the analogue of NMR over the entire visible and infrared regions of the spectrum and has begun the work of disseminating the technology so it can reach the original promise of the laser. There are a number of issues that needed to be addressed to reach the goal of dissemination. The largest impediment was developing a commercial laser system with the capabilities to correct the light pulses for the changes in their direction and positions in time and space so they could interact with each other inside a sample. Working in collaboration with Light Conversion in Lithuania, we build a prototype laser system that both implemented our method and covered the entire spectrum from the ultraviolet to the infrared. That system is now commercially available. We also developed a new instrument control system based on yaq software. The yaq project was developed through a collaboration with Bluesky, a DOE program for controlling highly complex instrumental systems. The project defines a new general-purpose standard for hardware control. The standard has some of the powerful features of facility scale standards while remaining simple enough for feasible implementation and maintenance in small research labs. We developed and patented the methods and systems for performing coherent multidimensional spectroscopy and its use for performing femtosecond measurements of dynamics using a multiphoton pump and multidimensional coherent probe. We used this system to study the mechanism by which vitamin B12 controls the function of enzymes in our body.  Its mechanism involves the destruction of a strong bond between a cobalt metal ion and carbon and the question is how the vibrational modes of vitamin B12 can collaborate to cause the scission of such a strong bond. Our work identified the coupling between the vibrational modes that are coupled to the electronic states that are responsible for the cobalt-carbon bond. This work is the first example of how Floquet state spectroscopy can probe and control chemical reactions.

The Broader Impact from this project is the dissemination of a new technology. We have reached the point where dissemination is possible. The next step is demonstrating how the methodology can solve problems in science, technology, and medicine that cannot be solved with other methods. Dissemination often requires developing a ?killer app?. We are collaborating with multiple people to develop such apps. The most exciting is extending our work with vitamin B12 to synthetic chemistry applications where lasers can control chemical reactions.
